Applied to functions between sets of real numbers, this leads to the concepts of continuity, derivative, integral.

Historically, we find the earliest use of such limit methods in the work of the ancient Greeks. A famous example is Archimedes’ method of exhaustion to computing the area of a disk.
Even earlier, Zeno describes scenarios each of which is based upon some infinite process. The process is manipulated in a skillfully incorrect way to arrive at a
paradoxical conclusion
See details of this paradox
.
Appears here for his approach to computing the area of a disk.

Systematic, yet informal and intuitive use of infinite process and their limits started in the second half of the 17th century, notably with the invention of differential and integral calculus: Newton, Leibniz. The early development of mathematical analysis was driven significantly by the desire to place such intuitive use of limits on a solid foundation: Cauchy, Weierstraß, etc. Now, apart from being a vast subject in its own right, mathematical analysis has branched of into generalizations: points set topology, measure theory, operator theory, ... which carry their own names.
